name: Tuskegee Airmen National Historic Site
description: Before the first African American military pilots became known as the "Red Tails" they wore striped tails as they began their flight training in the Army's PT-17 Stearman bi-plane. Their flying adventure started at Moton Field, in Tuskegee, Alabama, where the Army Air Corps conducted a military test to determine if African Americans could be trained to fly combat aircraft.
shortDescription: Before the first African American military pilots became known as the "Red Tails" they wore striped tails as they began their flight training in the Army's PT-17 Stearman bi-plane. Their flying advent...

operatingHours.description: The park is open Monday-Saturday 9:00 am - 4:30 pm CST.  The park is closed Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, and New Year's Day.

climate.weatherDescription: The weather in Tuskegee is generally sunny, averaging around 218 sunny days annually. Average rainfall is 52 inches a year, with an average snowfall of 0 inches. The high temperature in July is around 92 degrees, and average low in January is around 42 degrees.

images.title: The "Duchess Arlene" -  flown by Robert Williams, Pilot class
images.altText: Red-Tail P-51D Mustang In Flight Exhibit
images.caption: One of the most beloved and recognized airplanes of World War II -  North American P-51D Mustang

images.title: Training Days at Tuskegee
images.altText: A World War II flight simulator and PT-17 bi-wing training plane
images.caption: Take a  "Walk Back In Time" in Hangar #1 to see the faces and visit the places where cadets trained as America's first African-American military pilots and support crews.

images.title: And There Were Women...
images.altText: Female Mechanic works on military aircraft
images.caption: Many are amazed to learn of the vital role women played as part of the Tuskee "Airmen" Experience.

images.title: First Flight - Eleanor Roosevelt was the first First Lady to fly with a Negro Pilot.
images.altText: Small Yellow training plane used in the Civilian Pilot Training Prograj - J3 Piper Cub
images.caption: Visitors are surprised to see the small size of the airplane in which First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt took a flight with Negro Pilot Charles A. Anderson.

images.title: History Lives at Moton Field
images.altText: Two airplane hangars - Hangar #1 in foreground and Hangar #2 in background at Moton Field.
images.caption: Come, experience the "power of place" where the Tuskegee Airmen blazed a trail that led to the civil rights movement.of the 1950's and 1960's.
